description.narrative: As mentioned, the Inclusive Peace in Practice initiative will begin with a 15 months inception phase during which the pilot programme for 2020-2022 will be designed. As the ambition is to challenge current practices and test new grounds, the outline of the programme as reflected in the proposal is indicative. The problem formulation is clear and LPI argues that experiences show that many local peacebuilders have limited belief in the global peacebuilding architecture, while those actors mediating decision-making at the global level - though well-intentioned - often seem to lack a substantive understanding or connection to grassroots peacebuilding. The initiative thus focuses primarily on how to transform this local-to-global engagement on global peacebuilding policies and norms that are currently - or on the verge of - being implemented. The theory of change is driven by the belief that greater equity, participation, and reciprocity between global decision-makers and local actors can shift norms over time and foster peacebuilding policy that is more directly connected to day-to-day lives, more effective and more sustainable. It is also mentioned that global peace agendas and frameworks for action in this way will become more legitimate in conflict areas for which they are developed. Following this line of reasoning, the overall goal is that: "Strategically selected global inclusive peace agendas, and their implementation, are influenced through tested models for collaborative policy engagement towards more reciprocal and mutually-beneficial local-to-global engagement". LPI has also shared indicative outcomes including selected outputs needed for progress towards the overall goal to give an idea of the nature of the programme to be. The outcomes are related to the generation of alternative evidence; the broadening of participation; and the transformation of engagement practices and norms. The inception phase will consolidate lessons within LPI on how to effectively influence policy change, identify leverage networks, and align the work in the Institute's programmes, its policy ambitions and knowledge and learning functions. In addition, the inception phase will develop a comprehensive assessment of the external landscape of global-level peacebuilding advocacy carried out by civil society, the state of the localisation of key inclusive peace frameworks in rhetoric and action, and the positions, interests and power of critical actors within this environment.

Initiativet Inclusive Peace in Practice 2018-2022 av the Life & Peace Institute (LPI) fokuserar främst på att förändra lokala-till-globala engagemang kring globala fredsbyggande policies och normer, som till exempel Sustaining Peace Agenda, diskursen kring Youth, Peace and Security (YPS) och Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), och på att främja större grad av inkludering i relevanta policyprocesser. Det drivs av tron på att mer jämlikhet, deltagande och reciprocitet mellan globala beslutsfattare och lokala aktörer kan ändra normer över tid och därmed främja fredsbyggande policies som är mer anpassade till den dagliga verkligheten i konfliktdrabbade områden, och därmed mer effektiva och mer hållbara. Ett centralt fokus, givet LPI:s engagemang i typiskt svåråtkomna områden, är att påverka policies i stängda, osäkra och informella miljöer. LPI drar även på sina partnerskap, erfarenheter från landprogrammen och sina beprövade metoder som till exempel ledsagande-modellen och Participatory Action Research-ansatsen.

The Inclusive Peace in Practice initiative 2018-2022 by the Life & Peace Institute (LPI) focuses primarily on how to transform the local-to-global engagement on global peacebuilding policies and norms, such as the Sustaining Peace Agenda, the Youth, Peace and Security (YPS) discourse and the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and to promote inclusion in relevant policy processes. It is driven by the belief that greater equity, participation, and reciprocity between global decision-makers and local actors can shift norms over time and foster peacebuilding policy that is more directly connected to day-to-day lives in conflict affected areas, and thus more effective and more sustainable. A key focus, given LPI's engagement in typical 'hard-to-reach' areas, is policy-influencing in closed, insecure and informal environments. LPI furthermore draws on its partnerships, experiences from country programmes and its tested methodologies such as the accompaniment model and the Participatory Action Research approach.
